hints.content: Start by understanding the input format. You have two lists: `keyName` which contains names of workers, and `keyTime` which contains the corresponding times they used their key-cards. Each entry in these lists is related by index.
Consider how to group the times by worker. You can use a dictionary to map each worker's name to a list of their corresponding key-card usage times.
Remember that the times are in 'HH:MM' format. You might want to convert these times into a more manageable format, such as the total number of minutes since midnight, to facilitate easy comparisons.
Think about how to check for the one-hour window. For each worker, after sorting their usage times, you can iterate through the list and check if there are three usages within any one-hour period.
When checking for the one-hour window, you can use a sliding window technique. Keep track of the start of the window and move the end of the window forward while counting the number of accesses.
Make sure to handle cases where the worker has fewer than three usages gracefully. You can skip any workers who do not meet this basic requirement.
As you identify workers who meet the alert criteria, store their names in a set to ensure uniqueness. This will help you avoid duplicates in your final output.
After processing all workers, sort the names alphabetically before returning them. Sorting can be done easily using built-in functions.
Pay attention to edge cases, such as workers who use their key-cards exactly three times at the boundary of the one-hour window. Ensure your logic correctly identifies these instances.
Finally, remember to return the list of names in the specified format. The output should be a list of unique worker names who triggered the alert, sorted in ascending order.

questionNotes: Input lists `keyName` and `keyTime` are of equal length.
Return a sorted list of unique names who used their key-card 3 or more times in a one-hour period.
